title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #384: Prime Divisors of Binomial Coefficients**

Is C(n,k) divisible by a prime p < n/2 for 1 < k < n-1?

**Status:** SOLVED by Ecklund (1969)
**Exception:** C(7,3) = 35 = 5 × 7 is the only case where all primes are ≥ n/2
mathContext: The binomial coefficient C(n,k) = n!/(k!(n-k)!) counts k-subsets of an n-set.

title: Small Prime Divisor Predicate
content:
**hasSmallPrimeDivisor n bound:** A number n has a prime divisor p with p < bound.

∃ p, p.Prime ∧ p ∣ n ∧ p < bound

This formalizes the key property we're proving about binomial coefficients.

title: The Unique Exception: C(7,3)
content:
**C(7,3) = 35 = 5 × 7** is the ONLY binomial coefficient with 1 < k < n-1 that has no prime divisor < n/2.

Why is this special?
- 35 = 5 × 7
- n/2 = 7/2 = 3.5
- Both primes 5 and 7 are ≥ 4

By symmetry, C(7,4) = 35 is also an exception.

title: Ecklund's Theorem (1969)
content:
**ecklund_1969:** For 1 < k < n-1, either:
- C(n,k) has a prime divisor < n/2+1, OR
- (n,k) ∈ {(7,3), (7,4)}

This is the main result of the problem, proved by Ecklund in 1969.

title: Ecklund's Stronger Conjecture
content:
**ecklundStrongConjecture:** If n > k² then C(n,k) has a prime divisor < n/k.

This is a significant strengthening of the n/2 bound. Status: PARTIALLY PROVED.

title: Selfridge's Conjecture
content:
**selfridgeConjecture:** If n > 17.125k then C(n,k) has a prime divisor ≤ n/k.

The constant 17.125 appears mysteriously. This conjecture is credited to Selfridge in Guy's collection.

title: Kummer's Theorem
content:
**kummer_theorem:** The exponent of prime p in C(n,k) equals the number of carries when adding k and n-k in base p.

This is the key tool for understanding prime divisibility of binomials. It explains why large primes rarely divide C(n,k) with high multiplicity.

title: Edge Cases
content:
**Edge cases k=1 and k=n-1:**

- C(n,1) = n has prime divisor minFac(n)
- C(n,n-1) = n by symmetry

These boundary cases are trivial since n itself is the value.

title: Small Cases Verification
content:
**Concrete verification for small n:**

- C(5,2) = 10 = 2 × 5, has prime 2 < 3
- C(6,2) = 15 = 3 × 5, has prime 3 < 4
- C(6,3) = 20 = 4 × 5, has prime 2 < 4

All small cases satisfy the theorem.

title: Central Binomial Primes
content:
**central_binomial_primes:** C(2n,n) always has a prime in (n, 2n].

This follows from Bertrand's postulate and is related to but distinct from the main problem.

title: Related Problems
content:
**Connections to other Erdős problems:**

- Problem #1094: Stronger version with different bounds
- Problem #1095: Another strengthening
- Guy's Problems B31, B33: Related questions in 'Unsolved Problems in Number Theory'

title: Main Result Summary
content:
**erdos_384_main:** The complete statement of Ecklund's theorem.

For 1 < k < n-1, C(n,k) has a prime divisor < n/2+1, except for the unique exception C(7,3) = C(7,4) = 35.

Status: SOLVED
